abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The adult, pupa, larva and biology of <jats:italic>Adenogasteria leguminivora</jats:italic> Davis & Vargas gen. et sp. nov. (Lepidoptera: Gracillariidae: Ornixolinae) from Peru and Chile are described and illustrated. This micromoth was previously reported in the agronomic literature as a pest of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Caesalpinia spinosa</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> (Molina) (Fabaceae) in Peru, but its taxonomic status remained unknown until now. Its larvae feed on the seeds of three legume trees: <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Acacia macracantha</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>C. spinosa</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> and <jats:italic>Inga feuillei</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>Adenogasteria leguminivora</jats:italic> superficially resembles other sympatric gracillariids but can be separated on key morphological features and host plant preferences. Eggs of <jats:italic>A. leguminivora</jats:italic> are laid on the fruit surface, from where the larva burrows until it reaches the cotyledons, which are mined by the two early (sap‐feeding) instars and almost completely consumed by the last three (tissue‐feeding) instars. Subsequently, the mature larva leaves the fruit and constructs an elongated silk cocoon ornamented with a few silk bubbles before pupation. A maximum likelihood analysis of DNA barcodes clustered the <jats:italic>A. leguminivora</jats:italic> sequences as a single independent phylogenetic unit within Ornixolinae, sister to the <jats:italic>Chileoptilia</jats:italic> + <jats:italic>Philodoria</jats:italic> clade, regardless of the host plant and geographic origin of the samples. The genetic divergence of <jats:italic>A. leguminivora</jats:italic> to the nearest neighbour in COI barcodes was >10%.</jats:p>
title: Adenogasteria leguminivora Davis & Vargas gen. et sp. nov. (Lepidoptera: Gracillariidae): a new seed‐feeding micromoth associated with Fabaceae in Peru and Chile
